subject: RE: [junit] Javadocing test case and other test classes?
msgSnippet: I m with Mike on this one. Test code is supposed to be small and very straight-forward, otherwise it ends up needing testing itself! So combine small/short
messageBody:
I'm with Mike on this one.

Test code is supposed to be small and very straight-forward, otherwise it ends up needing testing itself! So combine small/short code methods with very meaningful method names and I think that should be enough for all but the most complex tests.

If you have a complex test, then by all means write a standard comment in the code explaining what and why. But unless I had a customer who had contracted to receive documented unit tests, then I'd skip the JavaDoc as well.

As J.B. likes to say, they're programmer tests, written by programmers for themselves, so given that unit tests are not typically a deliverable, why document them over and above what YOU need to be able to understand them.

Just my 1/50th of a U.S. Federal Reserve Note.

Simon

>-----Original Message-----
>From: Kevin Klinemeier [mailto:zipwow@...]
>Sent: Wednesday, January 05, 2005 11:15 AM
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: Re: [junit] Javadocing test case and other test classes?
>
>
>
>Does that mean that you don't include a coment for the test method?
>FWIW again, I always include javadoc of the methods in my test
>classes, with a description of what the setUp is setting up, or what
>the test method is intended to do.
>
>From that point of view, if you're delivering the unit tests, and
>expecting them to do anything with it, I'd think you'd want to deliver
>the javadoc as well.
>
>-Kevin
>
>
>On Wed, 5 Jan 2005 09:21:48 -0700, Mike Clark
><mike@...> wrote:
>> FWIW, I don't deliver JavaDoc for test classes. I generally
>don't put
>> JavaDoc tags in my test classes, so any generated JavaDoc
>would simply
>> show the class and method names. You get that same information when
>> you run the tests.
>>
>> ---
>> Mike Clark
>> Clarkware Consulting, Inc.
